goals.question: What is the distribution of budget amounts across different categories?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of budget amounts by category
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand which categories have the highest and lowest budgets, and identify any outliers or anomalies.

goals.question: What is the trend in budget amounts over time?
goals.visualization: Line chart of budget amounts by year
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand whether the budget amounts have been increasing, decreasing, or staying the same over time, and identify any patterns or trends.

goals.question: What is the distribution of budget amounts by department?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of budget amounts by department
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand which departments have the highest and lowest budgets, and identify any areas where budget cuts or increases may be needed.

goals.question: What is the proportion of budget allocated to salaries and wages?
goals.visualization: Pie chart of budget allocation between salaries and wages and other expenses
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the proportion of the budget that is allocated to salaries and wages, and identify any areas where cost savings may be possible.

goals.question: What is the correlation between budget amounts and actual spending?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of budget amounts vs actual spending
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the relationship between budget amounts and actual spending, and identify any areas where budgeting may need to be adjusted to better reflect actual spending.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('budgets.json')

# Plot
sns.barplot(x='category', y='amount', data=data)
plt.title('What is the distribution of budget amounts across different categories?')
plt.ylabel('Budget Amount')
plt.xlabel('Category')
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('budgets.json')

# Convert date field to datetime type
data['year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['year'], format='%Y')

# Line chart of budget amounts by year
sns.lineplot(x='year', y='amount', data=data)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the trend in budget amounts over time?', wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('budgets.json')

# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.barplot(x='department', y='budget', data=data, palette='Blues_d')
plt.title('What is the distribution of budget amounts by department?')
plt.xlabel('Department')
plt.ylabel('Budget')
plt.tight_layout()

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('budgets.json')

# Calculate the proportion of budget allocated to salaries and wages
salaries_wages = data['salaries_wages'].sum()
other_expenses = data['other_expenses'].sum()
total_budget = salaries_wages + other_expenses
salaries_wages_proportion = salaries_wages / total_budget
other_expenses_proportion = other_expenses / total_budget

# Create a pie chart
labels = ['Salaries and Wages', 'Other Expenses']
sizes = [salaries_wages_proportion, other_expenses_proportion]
colors = ['#ff9999','#66b3ff']
fig1, ax1 = plt.subplots()
ax1.pie(sizes, colors = colors, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%', startangle=90)
ax1.axis('equal')
plt.title('What is the proportion of budget allocated to salaries and wages?', wrap=True)

# Show the chart
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_json('budgets.json')

# Create scatter plot
sns.scatterplot(x='budget_amount', y='actual_spending', data=data)

# Set chart title
plt.title('What is the correlation between budget amounts and actual spending?', wrap=True)

# Add regression line
sns.regplot(x='budget_amount', y='actual_spending', data=data, scatter=False)

# Add legend for regression line
plt.legend(['Regression line'])

# Return plot
plt.show()
```
